title: Ka-wayawayama: Aeroplane Dance
viewing_guidelines: Aboriginal and Islander viewers should note this work may contain images of deceased people and caution should be exercised when viewing.
subject_group: Aboriginal Australia/Aboriginal Australians - Social life and customs
Aboriginal Australia/Aboriginal Australians - Rites and ceremonies
Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Rites and ceremonies
abstract: Tells the story of the crash of a US bomber through the diary of a survivor and the songs and dances of the Yanyuwa people who searched for the plane.
description: Records the story of "Ka-wayawayama" or "Aeroplane Dance" of the Yanuwa people of the Borroloola area in the Northern Territory. The dance was created after an American "Liberator" bomber crashed in the area in 1942, after a mission in the South-west Pacific. Re-creates the plight of the flight crew in their trek across inhospitable terrain across the Gulf of Carpentaria and the search for the lost crew.
